{{about|homeless newspapers|other alternative newspapers|Street press}}
[[File:Street-sheet-saleswoman-crop.jpg|right|250px|thumb|A street newspaper vendor, selling ''[[Street Sheet]]'', in [[San Francisco]]]]
'''Street newspapers''' (or '''street papers''') are [[newspaper]]s or [[magazines]] sold by [[homelessness|homeless]] or [[poverty|poor]] individuals and produced mainly to support these populations. Most such newspapers primarily provide coverage about homelessness and poverty-related issues, and seek to strengthen social networks within homeless communities. Street papers aim to give these individuals both employment opportunities and a voice in their community. In addition to being sold by homeless individuals, many of these papers are partially produced and written by them.
In the late 19th and early 20th centuries several publications by charity, religious, and labor organizations tried to draw attention to the homeless, but street newspapers only became common after the founding of New York City's ''[[Street News]]'' in 1989. Similar papers are now published in over 30 countries, with most located in the United States and Western Europe. They are supported by governments, charities, and coalitions such as the [[International Network of Street Papers]] and the [[North American Street Newspaper Association]]. Although street newspapers have multiplied, many still face challenges, including funding shortages, unreliable staff and difficulty in generating interest and maintaining an audience.
Street newspapers are sold mainly by homeless individuals, but the newspapers vary in how much content is submitted by them and how much of the coverage pertains to them: while some papers are written and published mainly by homeless contributors, others have a professional staff and attempt to emulate mainstream publications. These differences have caused controversy among street newspaper publishers over what type of material should be covered and to what extent the homeless should participate in writing and production. One popular street newspaper, ''[[The Big Issue]]'', has been a focus of this controversy because it concentrates on attracting a large readership through coverage of mainstream issues and [[popular culture]], whereas other newspapers emphasize homeless advocacy and social issues and earn less of a profit.
== History == [[File:Hobo News cover.jpg|thumb|An early ''[[Hobo News]]'' front page]]
=== Historical foundations === Although the modern street newspaper began with the 1989 publication of ''[[Street News]]'' in [[New York City]],<ref name=CSM>{{cite web | last=Harman | first=Danna | date=17 November 2003 | accessdate=13 January 2009 | work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] | url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/1117/p13s01-lihc.html | title=Read all about it: street papers flourish across the US}} [http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/1117/p13s01-lihc.htm Archived version]</ref><ref name=UNESCO>{{cite web | last=Boukhari | first=Sophie | title=The press takes to the street | url=https://www.questia.com/read/1G1-54237636/the-press-takes-to-the-street | publisher=[[UNESCO]] | work=[[The UNESCO Courier]] | year=1999 | accessdate=13 March 2009}}</ref> and the Street Sheet in San Francisco, 1989, newspapers sold by the poor and homeless to generate income and to bring attention to social problems date back to the late 19th century; [[journalism]] scholar Norma Fay Green has cited ''[[The War Cry]]'', created by the [[Salvation Army]] in [[London]] in 1879, as an early form of "dissident, underground, alternative publication".<ref name=Howley62>{{Harvnb|Howley|2005|p=62}}</ref> ''The War Cry'' was sold by [[Officer of The Salvation Army|Salvation Army officers]] and the [[working poor]] to draw people's attention to the poor living conditions of these individuals. Another precursor to the modern street newspaper was [[Cincinnati]]'s<ref name=Dodge>{{cite journal | url=http://www.geocities.com/SoHo/Cafe/7423/streetpapers.html | last=Dodge | first=Chris | year=1999 | title=Words on the Street: Homeless People's Newspapers | journal=American Libraries | accessdate=15 April 2009 | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/SoHo/Cafe/7423/streetpapers.html&date=2009-03-17+09:45:51 | archivedate=2009-03-17 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref><ref name=Heinz534/> ''[[Hobo News]]'', which ran from 1915 to 1930<ref group=note>Another author claims the paper had a shorter lifespan, running "from the late 1910s to the early 1920s" {{Harv|Heinz|2004|p=534}}.</ref> and featured writing from prominent labor and social activists as well as [[Industrial Workers of the World]] members, alongside contributions of oral history, creative writing, and artwork from [[hobo]]es, or itinerant beggars.<ref name=Howley63>{{Harvnb|Howley|2005|p=63}}</ref> Most street papers published before 1970, such as ''[[The Catholic Worker]]'' (founded in 1933<ref name=Heinz535/>), were affiliated with religious organizations.<ref name=NASNA>{{cite web | url=http://www.nasna.org/stpaper.html | publisher=[[North American Street Newspaper Association]] | title=About Street Papers | date=7 November 2008 | accessdate=12 February 2009|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080225090632/http://www.nasna.org/stpaper.html |archivedate = February 25, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Like workers' papers and other forms of [[alternative media]] in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, early street newspapers were often created because the founders believed mainstream news did not cover issues that were relevant to ordinary people.<ref name=Heinz534>{{Harvnb|Heinz|2004|p=534}}</ref>
=== Modern street newspapers === Modern street newspapers began to emerge in the United States in the late 1980s in response to [[Homelessness in the United States#1980s|increasing levels of homelessness]] and homeless advocates' dissatisfaction with the [[mainstream media]]'s portrayals of the homeless.<ref>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=1}}</ref><ref name=Green47>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|p=47}}</ref> At the time, many media outlets portrayed homeless people as being all criminals and drug addicts, and suggested that homelessness was a result of laziness rather than societal or political factors.<ref name=Heinz535>{{Harvnb|Heinz|2004|p=535}}</ref> Thus, one motivation for the creation of the first street newspapers was to counter the negative coverage of homeless people that was coming from existing media.
''[[Street News]],'' founded in late 1989 in New York City, is frequently cited as the first modern street newspaper.<ref name=review/><ref name=Heinz536/> While some small papers were already being published when it was founded, ''Street News'' attracted the most attention and became the "catalyst" for many other papers.<ref name=enemy>{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051103184723/http://www.realchangenews.org/pastarticles/features/articles/fea_nasnaspch.html | archivedate=3 November 2005 | url=http://www.realchangenews.org/pastarticles/features/articles/fea_nasnaspch.html | date=14 September 1997 | last=Harris | first=Timothy | title=Strength in Unity: Street Newspaper Must Not Be Its Own Enemy | work=Founding Conference of the North American Street Newspaper Association | publisher=[[Real Change]] | accessdate=13 March 2009}}</ref> Many more street papers were launched in the early 1990s,<ref name=UNESCO/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sf-homeless-coalition.org/eng/about/#strshe | accessdate=13 January 2009 | title=Get Acquainted | publisher=[[Coalition on Homelessness, San Francisco]] | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081010182419/http://www.sf-homeless-coalition.org/eng/about/#strshe | archivedate=10 October 2008 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Big Issue History |url=http://www.bigissue.com/History_34.php |accessdate=13 January 2009 |publisher=[[The Big Issue]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301141303/http://www.bigissue.com/History_34.php |archivedate=1 March 2009 |df= }}</ref> crediting the high-profile New York paper as their inspiration, such as ''[[Spare Change News]]'' in [[Boston]] founded in 1992. During this period, an average of five new papers were created every year.<ref name=CSM/><ref name=NASNA/> This growth has been attributed both to changing attitudes and policies towards homeless individuals and to the ease of publishing provided by desktop computers;<ref name=CSM/><ref name=NASNA/><ref name=phil/> After 1989, at least 100 papers<ref name=PBS>{{cite web | title=Street News (transcript) | date=15 December 2004 | url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/media/july-dec04/streetnews_12-15.html | accessdate=12 February 2009 | work=[[The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer]] | publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]] | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312182150/http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/media/july-dec04/streetnews_12-15.html | archivedate=12 March 2008 | df= }}</ref> sprung up in over 30 countries.<ref name="members">The [[International Network of Street Papers]] alone has 94 member papers across 36 countries. {{cite web|url=http://www.street-papers.org/our-street-papers/ |title=Our Street Papers |publisher=[[International Network of Street Papers]] |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100706122621/http://www.street-papers.org/our-street-papers/ |archivedate=6 July 2010 |df= }}</ref> By 2008, an estimated 32 million people worldwide read street newspapers, and 250,000 poor, disadvantaged, or homeless individuals sold or contributed to them.<ref name=phil/>
[[File:Straatnieuws seller in Zoetermeer 2008.jpg|thumb|left|A vendor for ''[[Straatnieuws]]'' in [[Zoetermeer]], the [[Netherlands]]]] Street papers have been started in many major cities worldwide,<ref name=Howley20032>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=2}}</ref> mainly in the United States and [[Western Europe]].<ref name=Sthlm>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyaorganisationer.soch.lu.se/SituationSthlm.html |accessdate=12 February 2009 |last=Magnusson |first=Jan A |title=The transnational street paper movement |work=[[Situation Sthlm]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629073232/http://www.nyaorganisationer.soch.lu.se/SituationSthlm.html |archivedate=29 June 2006 |df= }}</ref><ref name=HanksSwith154/> They have especially proliferated in [[Germany]], which in 1999 had more street newspapers than the rest of Europe combined,<ref name=HanksSwith154/> and in [[Sweden]], where the street papers ''[[Aluma (street paper)|Aluma]]'', ''[[Situation Sthlm]]'' and ''[[Faktum]]'' won the 2006 grand prize award for journalism of the [[Swedish Publicists' Association]].<ref name="Holender">{{cite news | url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?a=547043 | title=De hemlösas tidningar prisades | last=Holender | first=Robert | date=22 May 2006 | work=[[Dagens Nyheter]] | language=Swedish | accessdate=11 February 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/ekot/arkiv.asp?DagensDatum=2006-05-22&Artikel=863076 |title=Röster åt utsatta fick publicistpris |date=22 May 2006 |work=[[Ekot]] |publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614004653/http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/ekot/arkiv.asp?DagensDatum=2006-05-22&Artikel=863076 |archivedate=14 June 2006 |df= }}</ref> Street papers have been established in some cities in Canada, Africa, South America, and Asia.<ref name=UNESCO/><ref name=phil>{{Harvnb|Corporal|2008}}</ref> Even within the United States, some street newspapers (such as [[Chicago]]'s bilingual ''Hasta Cuando'') are published in languages other than English.<ref name=Heinz538>{{Harvnb|Heinz|2004|p=538}}</ref>
In the mid-1990s, coalitions were established to strengthen the street newspaper movement. The [[International Network of Street Papers|International Network of Street Papers (INSP)]] (founded in 1994) and the [[North American Street Newspaper Association|North American Street Newspaper Association (NASNA)]] (founded in 1997) aim to provide support for street papers and to "uphold ethical standards".<ref name=Heinz539>{{Harvnb|Heinz|2004|p=539}}</ref> In particular, the INSP was established to help groups that were starting new street newspapers, to bring more mainstream media attention to the street newspaper movement during the 1990s, and to support interaction and cross-talk between street paper publishers and staff from different countries.<ref>{{Harvs|last=Hanks|last2=Swithinbank|year=1999|loc=pp. 155–6|nb=yes}}</ref> The INSP and the NASNA voted to combine their resources in 2006;<ref name=RealChange>{{cite web | url=http://www.realchangenews.org/2006/2006_06_28/directorscorner.html | date=5 October 2006 | accessdate=12 February 2009 | work=[[Real Change News]] | last=Harris | first=Timothy | title=Director's Corner|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060929140821/http://www.realchangenews.org/2006/2006_06_28/directorscorner.html |archivedate = September 29, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref> they have collaborated to found the [[Street News Service]], a project which collects articles from member papers and archives them on the internet.<ref name=Heinz539/> National street paper coalitions have also been formed in Europe (there is a national coalition in [[Italy]], and the [[Netherlands]] has the ''[[Straatmedia Groep Nederland]]'').<ref name=HanksSwith154>{{Harvs|last=Hanks|last2=Swithinbank|year=1999|loc=p. 154|nb=yes}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:Streetwise vendor 1.jpg|right|thumb|A vendor for ''[[StreetWise]]'' in [[Chicago]]]] Most street newspapers have three main purposes:<ref name=Heinz535/><ref name=INSPconcept>{{cite web | url=http://www.street-papers.org/the-street-paper-concept/ | title=The street paper concept | publisher=[[International Network of Street Papers]] | accessdate=19 April 2009}} {{dead link| date=June 2010 | bot=DASHBot}}</ref> * To provide income and job skills to the homeless and other marginalized individuals, who act as vendors of and often contributors to the newspapers * To provide coverage of, and to educate the general public about, issues pertaining to homelessness and poverty * To establish social networks within homeless communities and between homeless individuals and service providers
The defining characteristic of a street newspaper is that it is sold by homeless or marginalized vendors.<ref name=denver>{{cite web | url=http://www.westword.com/2009-02-19/culture/masterminds/ | accessdate=12 March 2009 | date=18 February 2009 | title=Meet the MasterMind Class of 2009 | work=[[Westword]] | last=Calhoun | first=Patricia}}</ref> While many street newspapers aim to provide coverage of social issues and educate the public about homelessness, this goal is often secondary: many people who buy street newspapers do so to support and express solidarity with the homeless vendor, rather than to read the paper.<ref name=Torck372/>
The precise demographics of the readership of street newspapers is unclear. A pair of 1993 surveys conducted by Chicago's ''[[StreetWise]]'' suggested that the paper's readers at the time tended to be college-educated, with slightly over half being female, and slightly over half unmarried.<ref name=Green42>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|p=42}}</ref>
=== Operations and business === Most street newspapers operate by selling the papers to homeless vendors for a fraction of the retail price (usually between 10% and 50%), after which the vendors sell the papers for the retail price and retain all the proceeds from street sales.<ref name=CSM/><ref name=NASNA/><ref name=Sthlm/><ref group=note>Some street newspapers, however, work differently, having vendors pay back a portion of the proceeds after selling the paper {{Harv|Corporal|2008}}.</ref> The income vendors earn from sales is intended to help them "get back on their feet".<ref name=NASNA/> The purpose of requiring vendors to purchase papers up front and earn back the money by selling them is to help them develop skills in financial management.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bigissue.com/How_We_Work_14.php | title=How We Work | publisher=The Big Issue | accessdate=10 February 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302154455/http://www.bigissue.com/How_We_Work_14.php | archivedate=2 March 2009 | df= }}</ref> Vendors for most newspapers are identifiable by badges<ref name=KU/><ref>{{cite web|title=About StreetWise Vendors |accessdate=13 January 2009 |url=http://streetwise.org/vendors.html |publisher=[[StreetWise]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090209053959/http://www.streetwise.org/vendors.html |archivedate=February 9, 2009 }}</ref> or messenger bags.<ref name=KU/> Many newspapers require that vendors sign a code of conduct<ref>Such as ''The Big Issue'': {{cite web | url=http://www.bigissue.com/How_We_Work_14.php | title=How We Work | publisher=[[The Big Issue]] | accessdate=13 January 2009 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302154455/http://www.bigissue.com/How_We_Work_14.php | archivedate=2 March 2009 | df= }}</ref> or otherwise "clean up their act".<ref name=CSM/>
Most street newspaper vendors in the United States and United Kingdom are homeless individuals, although in several other countries (especially in Europe) papers are mainly sold by [[refugee]]s.<ref>{{Harvs|last=Hanks|last2=Swithinbank|year=1999|loc=pp. 153–4|nb=yes}}</ref> Nevertheless, not all vendors are homeless; some have stable housing situations but are unable to hold other jobs, while others started out homeless but were eventually able to use their income from sales to find housing. In general, the major American street newspapers do not require prospective vendors to show proof of homelessness or poverty, and they do not require vendors to retire once they find stable housing.<ref name=hsu>{{cite web | url=http://www.seattleweekly.com/2007-04-11/news/not-all-the-peddlers-of-seattle-s-homeless-paper-are-homeless.php | work=[[Seattle Weekly]] | title=Not All the Peddlers of Seattle's Homeless Paper Are Homeless | last=Hsu | first=Huan | date=10 April 2007 | accessdate=14 March 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109183034/http://www.seattleweekly.com/2007-04-11/news/not-all-the-peddlers-of-seattle-s-homeless-paper-are-homeless.php# | archive-date=2009-01-09 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> In the United States, since 2008 there have been a growing number of vendors who are "newly needy"—only recently homeless, or with only temporary financial difficulty—as opposed to the "chronically homeless" who have traditionally made up the majority of the vendor force. These vendors are often well-educated and have extensive work experience, but lost their jobs in the [[2008 financial crisis]].<ref name=risingcirc>{{cite news | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=12 April 2009 | accessdate=13 April 2009 | title=Extra, Extra! Homeless Lift Street Papers, and Attitudes | last=Lorber | first=Janie | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/13/business/media/13street.html?_r=1}}</ref>
Street papers start in a variety of ways. Some, such as ''[[Street Sense (newspaper)|Street Sense]]'',<ref name=PBS/> are begun by homeless or formerly homeless individuals, whereas others are more professional ventures.<ref name=Sthlm/> Many, particularly in the United States, receive aid from local government and charities,<ref name=Sthlm/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.larryville.com/index.php/local-news/local-news/16-local-news/91-sweets-on-the-street-change-of-heart-lawrences-homeless-newspaper-is-ten-years-old-this-year | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130502145031/http://news.larryville.com/index.php/local-news/local-news/16-local-news/91-sweets-on-the-street-change-of-heart-lawrences-homeless-newspaper-is-ten-years-old-this-year | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2 May 2013 | accessdate=12 February 2009 | date=7 December 2006 | last=Roy | first=M.G. | title=Sweets on the Street: Change of Heart, Lawrence's homeless newspaper is ten years old this year | work=The Lawrencian}} </ref> and coalitions such as the International Network of Street Papers and the North American Street Newspaper Association provide workshops and support for new street papers.<ref name=Heinz539/> Many develop in a bottom-up fashion, starting up through volunteer work and "newcomers to the media business" and gradually expanding to include professionals.<ref name=Sthlm/><ref name=Green38>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|p=38}}</ref> For most papers, the majority of revenue comes from sales, donations, and government grants, while some receive advertising revenue from local businesses.<ref name=Sthlm/><ref name=Heinz538/><ref name=Green41-2/> There has been some disagreement among street newspaper publishers and supporters over whether papers should accept advertising, with some arguing that advertising is practical and helps support the paper, and others claiming that many kinds of advertisements are inappropriate in a paper that is mainly geared towards the poor.<ref name=Howley20039>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=9}}</ref>
Specific business models for street newspapers vary widely, ranging from vendor-managed papers that place the highest value upon homeless empowerment and involvement to highly professionalized and commercialized weeklies.<ref name=UNESCO/> Some papers (especially in Europe) operate as autonomous businesses, while others operate as parts of existing organizations or projects.<ref name=HanksSwith155>{{Harvs|last=Hanks|last2=Swithinbank|year=1999|loc=p. 155|nb=yes}}</ref> There are papers that are very successful, such as the UK-based ''The Big Issue'', which in 2001 sold nearly 300,000 copies a week and earned the equivalent of 1 million<ref>https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/06771432/filing-history</ref>[[United States dollar|USD]] in profits, but many papers sell as few as 3,000 copies a month and barely generate a profit at all for the publishers.<ref name=UNESCO/>
=== Coverage === Most street newspapers report on issues regarding homelessness and poverty,<ref name=UNESCO/> sometimes functioning as a main source of information on policy changes and other practical issues that are relevant to the homeless but may go unreported in mainstream media.<ref name=Howley20038>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=8}}</ref> Many feature contributions from the homeless and the poor in addition to articles by [[activist]]s and [[community organizer]]s,<ref name=Howley63/><ref name=NASNA/> including profiles of individual street newspaper vendors.<ref name=Heinz538/><ref name=Howley20039/><ref>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|pp=43–4}}</ref> For example, the first edition of [[Washington, D.C.]]'s ''[[Street Sense (newspaper)|Street Sense]]'' included a description of a prominent homeless community, an interview with a congresswoman, an editorial about the costs and benefits of taking a job, several poems about homelessness, a how-to column, and a section for recipes.<ref name=CSM/> A 2009 issue of the [[Lawrence, Kansas]]-based ''[[Change of Heart (street paper)|Change of Heart]]'' included a story on the recent bulldozing of a homeless camp, a review of a book on homelessness, a description of the Family Promise organization for homeless support, and a list of community resources;<ref>Ed. Craig Sweets. ''Change of Heart'': A voice for Lawrence's Homeless People. Vol. 12, no. 1 (Winter 2009).</ref> much of this content was submitted by the homeless.<ref name=KU>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansan.com/stories/2007/aug/23/newspaper/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20081201200413/http://www.kansan.com/stories/2007/aug/23/newspaper/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 December 2008 |work=[[University Daily Kansan]] |accessdate=13 January 2009 |title=Lawrence Streetpaper receives grant |last=Condron |first=Courtney |date=23 August 2007 }}</ref> The writing style is often simple and clear; social scientist Kevin Howley describes street newspapers as having a "native eloquence".<ref>{{Harvnb|Howley|2005|p=64}}</ref>
According to Howley, street newspapers are similar to [[citizen journalism]] in that both are a response to the perceived shortcomings of the mainstream media and both encourage involvement by non-professionals. A major difference between the two, however, is that the citizen journalism movement does not necessarily advocate a particular position, whereas street newspapers openly advocate for the homeless and poor.<ref>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|pp=1–2; 7}}</ref>
Unlike most street newspapers, the [[United Kingdom|UK]]-based ''The Big Issue'' focuses mostly on celebrity news and interviews, rather than coverage of homelessness and poverty.<ref name=CSM/> It is still sold by homeless vendors and uses the bulk of its proceeds to support homeless individuals and advocacy organizations for the homeless, but the paper's content is mostly written by professional staff and geared towards a broad audience.<ref name=review/> Because of its professional nature and high production values, it has been a frequent target of criticism in an ongoing debate between adherents of professional and [[grassroots]] ideals of how street newspapers should work.<ref name=Sthlm/><ref name=Howley200311/>
=== Social benefits === In addition to providing some individuals with income and employment, street newspapers are intended to give homeless participants responsibility and independence, and to create a tight-knit homeless community.<ref name=CSM/><ref>[[Lee Stringer|Stringer, Lee]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=uX2Ol9BnT_gC ''Grand Central Winter: Stories from the Street''], 1st ed., New York : Seven Stories Press, 1998. {{ISBN|1-888363-57-6}}. Cf. Chapter 6, "West Forty-sixth Street, Winter 1989" which is about his experiences as a vendor of ''Street News''. "But it's not just the easy money. For most of us vendors this old Blimpie's was like our clubhouse. We lingered here when we came for papers, milled around, worked the winter chill from our bones, traded stories of the street."</ref> Many offer additional programs to vendors, such as job training, housing placement assistance, and referral to other direct services. Others operate as a program of a larger social services organization—for instance, Chicago's ''StreetWise'' can refer vendors to providers of "drug and alcohol treatment, high school equivalency classes, career counseling, and permanent housing".<ref name=CSM/> Most are engaged in some form of organizing and advocacy regarding homelessness and poverty, and many function as "watchdogs" for the local homeless communities.<ref name=UNESCO/> Howley has described street newspapers as a means of mobilizing the networks of "formal and informal relationships that exist between the homeless, the unemployed, and the working poor, and shelter managers, healthcare workers, community organizers, and others who work on their behalf".<ref name=Howley63/>
=== Challenges and criticisms === [[File:EdMcLain.jpg|thumb|In 2005, [[Seattle]]'s ''[[Real Change]]'' redesigned its format and began to be published weekly, in attempt to avoid being seen as a "charity buy".<ref name=readers/>]] In the early days of street newspapers, people were often reluctant to buy from homeless vendors for fear that they were being scammed.<ref name=Green36>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|p=36}}</ref> Furthermore, many of the more activist papers fail to sell well because their writing and production are perceived to be unprofessional and lackluster. Topics covered are sometimes seen as lacking newsworthy content, and of little relevance or interest to the general public or the homeless community.<ref name=review>{{Harvnb|Brown|2002}}</ref><ref name=hone>"Homeless Journalists Hone Their Reporting Skills". American News Service, n.d. in {{Harvnb|Heinz|2004}}.<br />"[Street newspapers] have traditionally been long on personal essays and short on hard news".</ref> Organizations in [[Montreal]]<ref name=review/> and [[San Francisco]]<ref name=hone/> have responded to these criticisms by offering workshops in writing and journalism for homeless contributors. Papers such as ''StreetWise'' have in the past been criticized as "grim" and for having vendors that are too loud and intrusive.<ref>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|pp=40–1}}</ref> Some newspapers sell well but may not be widely read, as many people will donate to vendors without buying, or buy the newspaper and then throw it away.<ref name=Torck372>{{Harvnb|Torck|2001|p=372}}</ref><ref name=readers>{{cite web | last=Green | first=Sara Jean | title=Real Change's transformation includes plan to reach readers | work=[[Seattle Times]] | url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20050201&slug=homeless01m | date=1 February 2005 | accessdate=21 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|pp=36; 40}}</ref> Howley has described readers' hesitance or unwillingness to read the papers as "compassion fatigue".<ref name=Howley200310/> On the other hand, those papers that do sell well and are widely read, such as ''The Big Issue'', are often targets of criticism for being too "mainstream" or commercial.<ref name=review/><ref>Jacobs, Sally, "News is Uplifting for Homeless in N.Y.", ''The Boston Globe'', May 7, 1990</ref>
Other difficulties street newspapers face include high [[turnover (employment)|turnover]] of "transient" or unreliable staff,<ref name=review/><ref name=Howley200310>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=10}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|p=46}}</ref> lack of adequate funding,<ref name=review/><ref name=Heinz538/><ref name=Green41-2>{{Harvnb|Green|1998|pp=41–2}}</ref> lack of journalistic freedom for papers that are funded by local government, and, among some demographics, lack of interest in homeless issues. For example, journalism professor Jim Cunningham has attributed the difficulties in selling [[Calgary]]'s ''Calgary Street Talk'' to the fact that the mostly [[middle-class]], conservative population has "not enough sensitivity to the causes of homelessness".<ref name=review/> Finally, [[anti-homeless legislation]] often targets street newspapers and vendors; for example, in New York City and [[Cleveland]], laws have prevented vendors from selling papers on [[public transit]] or other high-traffic areas, making it difficult for the papers ''Street News'' and ''[[Homeless Grapevine]]'' to earn revenue.<ref name=Heinz538/>
=== Differing approaches === [[File:Bigissue.jpg|right|thumb|In part because of its "flashy" design and high production values, ''[[The Big Issue]]'' has been a source of controversy among street newspapers.]] Among proponents and publishers of street newspapers there is disagreement over how street newspapers should be run and what their goals should be, reflecting a "clash between two philosophies for advocating social change".<ref name=Howley200311>{{Harvnb|Howley|2003|p=11}}</ref> On one side of the debate are papers that seek to function like a business and generate a profit and a wide readership in order to benefit the homeless in a practical way; on the other are papers that seek to provide a "voice" to the homeless and poor without watering down their message for a broad readership.<ref name=Howley200311/> Timothy Harris, the director of ''[[Real Change]]'', has described the two camps as "liberal entrepreneurial" and "radical, grassroots activist".<ref name=enemy/>
Controversy surrounding ''The Big Issue'', the world's most widely circulated street newspaper,<ref name=review/><ref name=Heinz536/> is a good example of these two schools of thought.<ref group=note>Although ''The Big Issue'' has attracted attention and controversy because of its stature, it is not the only street newspaper that follows a business-oriented model. Numerous street newspapers work in a similar way, with ''The Big Issue'' being the most well-known example of a whole category of street newspapers {{Harv|Green|1998|p=47}}.</ref> ''The Big Issue'' is mostly a tabloid covering celebrity news; while it is sold by the homeless and generates a profit that is used to benefit the homeless, the content is not written by them and there is little coverage of social issues that are relevant to them.<ref name=CSM/> In the late 1990s when the London-based paper began making plans to enter markets in the United States, many American street newspaper publishers reacted defensively, saying they could not compete with the production values and mainstream appeal of the professionally produced ''The Big Issue''<ref name=UNESCO/><ref name=Howley200311/> or that ''The Big Issue'' did not do enough to provide a voice to the homeless.<ref name="Messman">{{cite web|url=http://hpn.asu.edu/archives/Feb98/0112.html|title=The Big Issue means big business as usual|last=Messman|first=Terry|date=10 February 1998|work=[[Street Spirit (newspaper)|Street Spirit]]|publisher=Homeless People's Network|accessdate=13 March 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630211539/http://hpn.asu.edu/archives/Feb98/0112.html|archivedate=30 June 2010|df=}}</ref> The reaction to ''The Big Issue'' raised what is now an ongoing conflict between commercialized, professional papers and more grassroots-style ones,<ref name=Heinz536>{{Harvnb|Heinz|2004|p=536}}</ref><ref name=Sthlm/> with papers such as ''The Big Issue'' emulating mainstream papers and magazines in order to generate a large profit to invest in homeless issues and others focusing on political and social issues rather than on content that will generate money.<ref name=UNESCO/> Some street newspaper proponents believe that the primary aim of the papers should be to give homeless individuals a voice and to "fill the void"<ref name=Green47/> in mainstream media coverage, whereas others believe it should be to provide homeless individuals with jobs and an income.<ref name=Howley200311/>
Other frequent areas of disagreement include the extent that the homeless should participate in the writing and printing of street newspapers,<ref name=review/> and whether street newspapers should accept advertising to generate revenue.<ref name=Howley20039/> Kevin Howley sums up the division between different street newspaper models when he questions if it is "possible (or desirable for that matter) to publish a dissident newspaper—that is, a publication committed to progressive social change—and still attract a wide audience".<ref name=Howley200311/>

Population |- | 1951 || 112 || 2005 || 116,544 |- | 1961 || 217 || 2006 || 113,068 |- | 1971 || 16,423 || 2007 || 108,189 |- | 1981 || 59,900 ||2008||108,762 |- | 1991 || 118,579 ||2009||109,985 |- | 1997 || 132,737 ||2010||111,302 |- | 1998 || 131,729 ||2011||112,461 |- | 1999 || 127,533 ||2012||112,917 |- |2000 |126,995 |2013 |113,670 |- |2001 |127,226 |2014 |114,740 |- |2002 |127,147 |2015 |115,433 |- |2003 |127,156 |2016 |116,026 |- |2004 |123,043 | | |} Turkish people were recruited to Austria as [[Gastarbeiter]] (guest workers) for the construction and export industries following an agreement with the Turkish government in 1964. From 1973 the policy of encouraging guest workers ended and restrictive immigration laws were introduced, first with the 1975 [[Aliens Employment Act]], setting quotas on work permits, and then the 1992 [[Residence Act]], which set quotas for residency permits without the right to work. A more restrictive system was put in place in 1997 and further limits imposed in 2006. Since the 1970s Turks living and working in Austria have focused on family reunification and on seeking Austrian citizenship, for which they need to have lived in Austria for 10 years. {{wide image|Avusturya Türk günü2.jpg|700px|Turkish day in [[Vienna]], Austria (2009).}} == Population == According to the 2001 census, there was 183,445 Turkish nationals living in Austria. According to the [[Minority Rights Group International]] many of the Turks living in Austria have been naturalized and the full community is estimated to number between 200,000 and 300,000. Turks are the largest single immigrant group, the leading group seeking Austrian citizenship, and account for the majority of Muslims.{{cite web|author=Minority Rights Group International|title=Turks|url=http://www.minorityrights.org/1907/austria/turks.html|accessdate=2009-01-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429201941/http://www.minorityrights.org/1907/austria/turks.html|archivedate=2009-04-29|df=}}According to BBC the number of Turks in Austria are estimated to be around 350,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-11725311|title=Turkey's ambassador to Austria prompts immigration spat|work=BBC News}} == Demographics == {{see also|Demographics of Austria}} {| cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" width=250 align="right" rules="all" style="margin: 1em; background: #ffffff; border: 2px solid #aaa; font-size: 100%;" |- bgcolor=#DDDDDD | colspan=8 align="center" | Turkish Citizens in Austria{{Harvnb|Matzka|2009|loc=3}}. |- bgcolor=#f0f0f0 align="center" ! {{Infobox women by region | image = Pleureuse.jpg | caption = Two modern-day women in Belgium | gii = 0.068 (2013) | gii_rank = 9th out of 152 | gii_ref = <ref name=gii>{{cite web|title=Table 4: Gender Inequality Index|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/table-4-gender-inequality-index|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> | matdeath = 8 (2010) | womparl = 38.9% (2013) | femed = 77.5% (2012) | womlab = 58% ([[employment rate]] [[OECD]] definition, 2015)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#|title=LFS by sex and age - indicators|first=|last=OECD|date=|website=stats.oecd.org|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> | ggg = 0.7684 (2013) | ggg_rank = 11th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} {{Community and region map of Belgium}} '''Women in Belgium''' are [[European women]] who live in or are from [[Belgium]]. Generation after generation, Belgian women are able to close the "occupational gender gap". In younger generations, this is due to the increasing availability of "[[part-time]] jobs in services" for women. In 1999, the average earnings of a Belgian woman was 91 percent of the [[salary]] of a Belgian man. When not doing [[part-time]] jobs, Belgian women still "do more of the [[Domestic worker|domestic work]]", depending on the agreement between female and male [[Domestic partnership|partners]].<ref>{{cite web|last=De Lannoy, Jean and Ruben A. Lombaert|title=Belgium|url=http://www.everyculture.com/A-Bo/Belgium.html|publisher=Advameg, Inc.|accessdate=26 October 2013}}</ref>
==Cultural background== {{See|Culture of Belgium|Communities, regions and language areas of Belgium}} Belgian culture is complex, because it has both aspects that are shared by most Belgians regardless of the language they speak, as well as differences between the main cultural communities: the Dutch-speaking [[Flemish people|Flemish]] and the French-speakers [[Walloons]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/A-Bo/Belgium.html|title=Culture of Belgium - history, people, women, beliefs, food, customs, family, social, marriage|work=everyculture.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> The [[Flemish people|Flemish]] draw intensively from both the [[English-speaking culture]] (which dominates sciences, professional life and most news media) and the [[Culture of the Netherlands|Netherlands]], while French-speakers focus on cultural life in [[Culture of France|France]] and elsewhere in the [[Francophone|French-speaking world]], and less outside. Today, the [[Brussels-Capital Region]] is primarily French speaking, but is quite bilingual, and is also a cosmopolitan place. There is also a small German speaking community in the East of the country. Women's rights in Belgium have been influenced by a variety of factors, including local culture, and national laws and policies. Women obtained the right to vote first with restrictions in 1919, and on equal terms with men in 1948.<ref name="idea.int">{{cite web|url=http://www.idea.int/publications/voter_turnout_weurope/upload/chapter%204.pdf |title=inlay_eurpean 1-12.qxd |format=PDF |website=Idea.int |date= |accessdate=2016-06-17}}</ref> Women obtained the right to stand for elections in 1921.<ref name="idea.int"/>
==Marriage and family life== Like in most other European countries, [[family law]] has traditionally given legal authority to the husband; but has been reformed in the second half of the 20th century. The [[marital power]] of the husband was abolished in 1958, but property laws were reformed only in the 1970s, when legal gender equality between husband and wife was established.<ref>''The Oxford Encyclopedia of Women in World History'', by Bonnie G. Smith, pp 332.</ref> [[Adultery]] was decriminalized in 1987.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.be/www/?MIval=/publications/viewPub.html&COLL=S&LEG=4&NR=162&VOLGNR=1&LANG=fr|title=Document législatif n° 4-162/1|work=senate.be|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> [[Same-sex marriage in Belgium]] was legalized in 2003. The [[divorce law in Belgium]] was liberalized in September 2007. In the 21st century, the link between [[marriage]] and [[fertility]] has decreased: in 2012, 52.3% of births were outside of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&plugin=1&language=en&pcode=tps00018|title=Eurostat - Tables, Graphs and Maps Interface (TGM) table|work=europa.eu|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> The centrality of marriage in peoples' life is no longer so strong: in the European Values Study (EVS) of 2008, the percentage of respondents who agreed with the assertion that "Marriage is an outdated institution" was 34.3% in Belgium.<ref>[http://zacat.gesis.org/webview/index.jsp?study=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfStudy%2FZA4783&variable=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2FZA4783_V252&mode=documentation&submode=variable&top=yes&language=en] See: Variable Description - Family - Q 45.</ref>
==Reproductive rights and health== {{See|Abortion in Belgium}} Abortion laws in Belgium were liberalized in 1990.<ref name="baudouin">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/05/world/belgian-king-unable-to-sign-abortion-law-takes-day-off.html|title=Belgian King, Unable to Sign Abortion Law, Takes Day Off|date=5 April 1990|work=The New York Times|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> Abortion is legal until the twelfth week of pregnancy,<ref name="belgium">{{cite web|url=http://belgium.angloinfo.com/countries/belgium/abortion.asp|title=Living in Belgium|work=angloinfo.com|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> and it is required for a woman to receive counseling at least six days prior to the abortion and to check in with her doctor to monitor her health in the weeks after the procedure.<ref name="belgium" /> Abortions at later stages are permitted for medical reasons.<ref name="belgium" /> The [[maternal mortality]] rate in Belgium is 8.00 deaths/100,000 live births (as of 2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2223rank.html|title=The World Factbook|work=cia.gov|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> Like most Western countries, Belgium has to deal with low fertility levels and a [[sub-replacement fertility rate]]: the [[total fertility rate]] (TFR) is 1.7 children born/woman (est. of 2015),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2127rank.html|title=The World Factbook|work=cia.gov|accessdate=17 June 2016}}</ref> which is below the replacement rate of 2.1.
== Women in politics == The representation of women in [[Belgian Federal Parliament|parliament]] has been increasing steadily since 1995.<ref name=":0">"Women in Parliament in 2007: The Year in Perspective." ''Ipu.org''. Inter-Parliamentary Union, 2008. Web. 24 July 2017.</ref> In lower or single Houses after parliamentary renewals in 2007, women have taken 55 seats to account for 36.7%.<ref name=":0" /> In 2014, that number rose slightly to 57 accounting for 38% in the lower or single House.<ref name=":1">"Women in National Parliaments." ''Women in Parliaments: World Classification''. 1 July 2017. Web. 24 July 2017.</ref> Women in upper houses of parliament in 2007 was 27 out of 71, which was 38%.<ref name=":0" /> That number rose to 30 women accounting for 50% total in the upper house in 2014.<ref name=":1" /> Belgium has a law requiring political parties to nominate at least 33 percent women. The parties that do not meet the target face sanctions.<ref name=":0" />
== Women in the workforce == Belgium, like neighboring Netherlands, has a strong tradition of women fulfilling a predominantly domestic role, rather than a professional one.<ref>http://aei.pitt.edu/4560/1/4560.pdf</ref> [[Roman Catholicism]], the traditional [[religion in Belgium]], has supported different [[gender roles]] for men and women. However, from the 1990s onward, this has started to change. The occupational gender gap has been decreasing in recent years, especially among younger generations. However, the higher occupational rate of women is primarily due to an increase in part-time jobs. In 2011, 43.3% of employed women worked part-time, compared to only 9.2% of men.<ref name="ec.europa.eu">{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/gender-equality/files/epo_campaign/130911_epo_country_profile_belgium.pdf|title=Gender equality|author=|date=|website=European Commission - European Commission|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> There is also a strong segregation by field, and there are less women in Belgium working in STEM and engineering than the EU average.<ref name="ec.europa.eu"/>
The gender employment gap for highly educated women decreased to 7% in 2002, below the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]] average.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/gender-wage-gap-for-women|title=Gender wage gap for women {{!}} Eurofound|website=www.eurofound.europa.eu|language=en|access-date=2017-08-01}}</ref> However, the overall employment rate for women aged 20–64 years is 63.0% compared to 72.3% for men (in 2016).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/refreshTableAction.do?tab=table&plugin=1&pcode=t2020_10&language=en|title=Eurostat - Tables, Graphs and Maps Interface (TGM) table|author=|date=|website=ec.europa.eu|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> The gender employment gap for highly educated women is smallest in [[Flemish Region|Flanders]] and largest in [[Wallonia]].<ref name=":4" />

'''Zvakwana''' is an [[underground movement]] in [[Zimbabwe]], that came to light in 2004. Its name means "enough is enough" in the [[Shona language]], and in [[Sindebele language|Ndebele]] it translates to [[Sokwanele]]. (Sokwanele is also a part of the movement but appears to be more occupied with information dissemination).
Zvakwana appears to be responsible for clandestinely distributing resistance messages, graffiti, CDs of music, and [[condom]]s featuring their logo, a Z on a yellow background. They also run a [[website]] which the Zimbabwean government is trying to block from [[internet service provider]]s.
Opposition party [[Movement for Democratic Change – Tsvangirai|Movement for Democratic Change]] says they have no connection to Zvakwana, but share its values and support its efforts.
